newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan-China trade edges up in Jan-June yr/yr.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan-China trade edges up in Jan-June yr/yr.

text.p: Taiwan's trade with China grew only 0.1 percent year-on-year to US$10.44 billion in the first six months of 1996, a period of acute tension across the Taiwan Strait, the Board of Foreign Trade said on Tuesday.
Taiwan's exports to China rose 1.5 percent to $8.98 billion, accounting for 15.9 percent of Taiwan's total exports, the board said in in statement.
Imports from China declined 7.9 percent to $1.46 billion, accounting for 2.9 percent of the island's total imports. It was the second month in a row that imports from China showed negative growth.
During the January-June period, Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of $7.52 billion with China, up 3.6 percent from the same period a year ago.
The board attributed the slow trade growth to a reduction in China export rebate tax rate in January, which caused Taiwan-owned factories in China to advance their exports to before January.
The cut led in turn to a slowdown in Taiwan's processing material exports to China.

China, which has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province since a civil war separated them in 1949, held war games in the Taiwan Strait during the island's historic direct presidential elecion on March 23 to warn voters not to support independence.
Officials have said the war games affected Taiwan firms' willingness to invest in China.
Some 30,000 Taiwan firms have poured US$20 billion in investments in China so far.
